main event: A pilot of a T-33 type aircraft observed a whitish-green light that passed the aircraft from starboard to port side at a high rate of speed, appearing to be 1 to 1 1/2 feet in diameter and cylindrical in shape.
interesting points: The object appeared to fire a small object that was observed to the rear of the main object at an approximate speed of 1,000 miles per hour for approximately 2 to 3 seconds before the object distinguished into a ball of fire.

The ATIC contract astronomer stated that the object observed was a meteor, and the fact that the object appeared to climb was probably caused by the motion of the aircraft as it turned to avoid collision.
The report concludes that the object was astronomical (a meteor).
The pilot was certain the object was not a star, planet, or any known type of aircraft or celestial body, and it was not affected by cloud cover encountered during the sighting.
The pilot reported the incident immediately upon landing.
sighted object: a whitish-green light, appearing to be 1 to 1 1/2 feet in diameter and cylindrical in shape
location: Newton, Mississippi to Lake Charles, Louisiana
witnesses: pilot of a T-33 type aircraft
